abstract.p: South Korea's top economic officials reach modest breakthrough with bank union representatives, by getting labor officials to join working-level to discuss specific issues; Korea Financial Industrial Union has threatened to strike if government continues with its industry revamping, beginning witgh placement of weaker banks under financial holding company (S)

block.p: At an 11th-hour meeting, South Korea's top economic officials reached a modest breakthrough with bank union representatives, by getting labor officials to join a working-level committee to discuss specific issues through the night. The 65,000-member Korea Financial Industrial Union has threatened to strike, perhaps as early as today, if the government continues with its current round of financial industry revamping, beginning with the placement of weaker banks under a financial holding company.

At an 11th-hour meeting, South Korea's top economic officials reached a modest breakthrough with bank union representatives, by getting labor officials to join a working-level committee to discuss specific issues through the night. The 65,000-member Korea Financial Industrial Union has threatened to strike, perhaps as early as today, if the government continues with its current round of financial industry revamping, beginning with the placement of weaker banks under a financial holding company.
